review.title: The Utility of Text: The Case of Amicus Briefs and the Supreme Court
review.abstract: We explore the idea that authoring a piece of text is an act of maximizing one's expected utility. To make this idea concrete, we consider the societally important decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States. Extensive past work in quantitative political science provides a framework for empirically modeling the decisions of justices and how they relate to text. We incorporate into such a model texts authored by amici curiae ("friends of the court" separate from the litigants) who seek to weigh in on the decision, then explicitly model their goals in a random utility model. We demonstrate the benefits of this approach in improved vote prediction and the ability to perform counterfactual analysis.

sections.heading: 5.4 Discussion
sections.text: Our model is based on several simplistic assumptions: (i) it ignores the impact of other amici on the writing of a single amicus; (ii) amici are treated modular, with a multiplicative effect and without taking into account diminishing returns, temporal order or reputation; (iii) the cost function does not capture the intricacies of legal writing (i.e. selection of quotes, artful language, etc.); (iv) the benefit function does not fully capture the agenda of each amicus; (v) each amicus assignment is treated independently (i.e. no passing on of writings to the same author) because we do not have access to clean author metadata. Despite these simplifications, the model is a useful tool for quantitative analysis and hypothesis generation in support of substantial research on the judiciary.

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: Poole and Rosenthal (1985) introduced the IP model by using roll-call data to derive latent legislative positions. Since then, many types of IP models have been proposed for different voting scenarios: IP models for SCOTUS (Martin and Quinn 2002), multidimensional IP models for congressional voting (Heckman and Snyder 1996; Clinton, Jackman and Rivers 2004), grounding multidimensional IP models using topics learned from congressional submissions (Gerrish and Lead 2012), and SCOTUS opinions (Lauderdale and Clark 2014). Amici have been extensively studied, in particular their influence on SCOTUS (Caldeira and Wright 1988; Kearney and Merrill 2000; Collins 2008; Corley, Collins and Hamner 2013). Collins (2007) found that justices can be influenced by compelling arguments presented by organized interests. These studies focus on ideological metadata (liberal / conservative views, etc.).

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: We have introduced a random utility model for compelling text; it resembles a classical generative model and can be estimated using familiar algorithms; the main difference is that compelling text is modelled according to the addressee and the details of the matter it is convinced of; authors are agents who seek to maximise their expected benefit in a given scenario. In the SCOTUS area, this leads to improved election forecasting, as the model captures the structure of amicus fonts better than simpler treatments of the text. Second, and more importantly, our model is able to answer interesting counterfactual questions.
